repnme.cdata!:
Guinea-Bissau - Private Sector
            Rehabilitation and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Sector
            Rehabilitation and Development Project for Guinea-Bissau
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory,
            the risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: in a context of fragile institutions,
            special attention should be paid to the political economy
            and 'second best' solutions should be explored.
            One of the key elements of reform that was emphasized
            throughout the project was the development of a
            multi-sectoral regulatory agency. Such an agency never
            became operational and was possibly rarely considered
            seriously by the changing Governments. As discussed above,
            the political instability and the complexity of unbundling
            the existing vested interests at the level of individual
            ministries (which were sensitive to the resources generated
            through the sectoral regulatory agencies) are the key
            reasons behind this outcome. Early recognition of the
            strength of these vested interests could potentially have
            allowed for the exploration of alternative, more politically
            feasible, routes of reform. The monitoring and evaluation
            (M&E) framework should receive greater priority even in
            a weak institutional setting in order to support both a
            quantitatively sound evaluation and project implementation.
            The lack of a satisfactory M&E framework makes it
            difficult to adequately assess the impact of the project,
            and therefore limits the ability to make corrections or draw
            lessons for future projects. The lack of adequate M&E
            doubtless limited the ability to measure the degree to which
            specific components achieved the desired goals or should
            have been modified in order to accomplish those goals.

5077713.majtheme: Rule of law,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea-Bissau - Private Sector
            Rehabilitation and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Private
            Sector Rehabilitation and Development Project for
            Guinea-Bissau is to support increased investment,
            competitiveness, and participation of the private sector in
            economic activity. There are three project components. The
            first component supports and/or prepares the reform of
            telecommunications, air transport, port, water, and energy
            sectors. The project assists in attracting private
            investments in these sectors and in the implementation of
            the necessary legal and regulatory reforms, and funds
            related capacity building, especially in a multi-sector
            regulatory agency. In addition, this component supports
            divestiture from public enterprises, including the
            liquidation of a bankrupt commercial bank and the
            outsourcing of custodial public services. The project
            finances the retrenchment cost of redundant workers. The
            second component helps implement legal reform by modernizing
            business laws and making fair and equitable justice more
            readily available to individuals and private enterprises.
            Activities include improving institutional capacity in the
            main tribunal of Bissau, which handles most of the business
            cases; harmonization of national laws with the Organization
            for the Harmonization of Business Laws in Africa (OHADA);
            and providing complementary training and technical
            assistance to strenghten the judicial system and the legal
            profession. The third component supports implementation, and
            monitoring and evaluation.

692969.trustfund: TF040444-GUINEA-BISSAU:  PSD PROJECT,TF029582-PHRD-PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT CREDIT

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea-Bissau - Private Sector
            Rehabilitation and Restructuring Project (PSRRP) :
            environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental pre-audit
            assessment of seventeen public enterprises in the Republic
            of Guinea-Bissau that are being privatized under the Private
            Sector Rehabilitation and Restructuring Project. It aims to
            provide the necessary information for internal planning
            before divestiture and for external reporting as well as
            indicating the "road map" for determining the
            environmental liabilities and audit studies for future
            privatization candidates. The major environmental issues of
            concern in Guinea-Bissau include deforestation, soil
            degradation, overgrazing, and over-fishing. The
            industrialization could become accelerated through the
            privatization of public enterprises. This could give rise to
            critical and most immediate problems: a) health impacts of
            pollution derived from inadequate water supply and shortage
            of electricity; b) poor sanitation, drainage, and solid
            waste services; c) Poor urban and industrial waste
            management; d) air pollution; and e) noise pollution. In
            general, there is relatively low coverage and access to
            basic services. Controlled landfills, incineration, and
            resource recovery facilities are few. Hence, health and
            safety issues, including medical monitoring and providing
            appropriate industrial hygiene for workers, will be
            necessary to minimize the negative impacts.
